title: Deactivate tenants
content:
The configuration and ingestion requests for the tenant are rejected with ‘x’ error code for the deactivated tenant. The data processing and other background processes will continue to execute for this tenant.

The following command deactivates the specified tenants: 

./op-tms-cli tenant deactivate -f inputs-short.yaml [-s] [-r]

where the different options available are:

Options Description
-f or --file path to the input YAML file that contains the tenant configurations.
-s or --silent option to run the command in silent mode where you are not prompted to pass any parameter values on CLI.
-r or --override option to provide passwords as part of the command and override the environment passwords set.

The command deactivates the tenant from Operations Cloud, then OPTIC Data Lake, and then IDM. Once a tenant is deactivated, you receive a similar response:

Starting tenant deactivate...
 
Executing tenant deactivation chain...
TenantOne  -  Deactivate tenant tasks initiated
TenantOne  -  Waiting for UIS tenant to be deactivated
  This may take few minutes...
TenantOne  -  UIS tenant deactivated
TenantOne  -  Waiting for ODL tenant to be deactivated
  This may take few minutes...
TenantOne  -  ODL tenant deactivated
TenantOne  -  IDM organization deactivated
TenantOne  -  Deactivate tenant tasks completed
 
 
Tenant deactivate completed

Here, TenantOne is an example of the tenant name.

You can run the following command to check the tenant state:

./op-tms-cli tenant exist -f inputs-short.yaml
